results.notes:
On the riparian zone of the Boise river, in a moist area with various hardwoods cottonwood dominant.
Fragile overall. Cap light brown, 5 cms, appendiculate in the young specimen, with a few fibrils around the margin, with a big patch of fibrils towards the center when older.
Stipe .4 cms wide., long as 3 of 4 times diameter.
Gills crowded and broad. Flesh thin.
No distinct odor or taste. Difficult to distinguish, even microscopically from other Psathyrella around cottonwood like Psathyrella subnuda.
Pleurocystidia utriform (33-40)x(12-16); cheilocystidia 38×12×8; basidia (19×21)x (7.5-9); spores smooth, elliptical (8-8.5) x (5-5.5).
results.location_name: Boise, Ada Co., Idaho, USA

results.notes: Small yellow fruitings on decaying wood (pine). Appears possibly asexual, very tiny spherical spores/conidia; conidiophore-like cells present on hymenium with single spore/conidia at apex; oily-resin(?) spherical masses appearing at hymenium edge and increasing in size within minutes, appear almost like air bubbles, but they were present on several mounts in KOH & water
results.location_name: Stockbridge, Henry Co., Georgia, USA

results.notes: On Ceanothus twigs. Thallus white, thin, no orange, faint black prothallus may be present where intersecting other lichens. Apothecia sessile, dark orange, epruinose, with a scarcely raised rim, about 0.5 mm. Proper margin present, thalline margin absent. Epihymenium of orange crystals extending around exciple to base, POL+ and C+R. Hymenium hyaline. Uncertain about oil drops? Algae only present in a small spot below exciple, not continuous across base. Pycnidia absent. Spores polarilocular, small. Average size: 11.2×5.8×4.3 (n=4).

results.notes:
Spores: Wide variation in spore size, maturity of spores unclear.Filiform, hyaline: 36, 26, 40, 41, 33, 33, 51 µm (longest observed), 2-4 µm wide at widest points. After using lighter method, spores appear clearly and consistently 3-septate.

Macro: thallus squamulose to subsquamulose, squamules overlapping in some areas. Thallus surface very dark olive green and shiny, almost appearing black. Apothecia +/- plane, black, with a roughened-looking surface. Micro: epithecium color indeterminate, may have needed thinner sections. Didn’t do much here outside of spore measurements and K and N test.

Chemistry: Epithecium K+V, N+ red-purple. The N reaction was very fast but think I caught some violet.

Comments: this keys easily to T. submexicana using Nash 2007 (K+V, N+V, and long, thin, 3-septate spores), and the macro looks a lot like one of our collections from a coastal ultramafic site that Jason D. ID’d as submexicana.

results.notes: I believe this was apparently growing from soil in a red oak, sugar maple, basswood forest. The slide is rather dark but not strongly color-caste. My scan has been brightened and the biggest difference is that in the slide the pale areas of the cap are mostly uniformly olive-yellow. Unfortunately I didn’t go further than this one shot. In case it isn’t obvious, the cap is rather strongly funnel-shaped. I hope maybe the distinctive combination of cap characters will be recognizable to someone. After all these years I would like to give this a name!

results.notes:
On ultramafic rock, usually in cracks.
Thallus squamulose, imbricate, greenish brown, POL-. Apothecia laminal, dark to blackish, mostly plane with raised rims, lacking algae in exciple. Epihymenium dark grey, K+V strong. Hymenium, hypothecium and exciple hyaline. Paraphyses segmented, capitate, brittle, often with a short branch near tip. Spores irregularly ellipsoid or narrowly ellipsoid, at times attenuated at one end, mostly (1) 3-septate, hyaline. Average size: 21.4×4.7 (n=7).
results.location_name: San Luis Obispo, San Luis Obispo Co., California, USA

results.notes:
On redwood bark (Sequoia sempervirens).
Thallus thin, white. Trentopohlia. Apothecia up to about 0.6mm, lecideine, black, convex, stipitate, epruinose, lacking raised rim and with smooth disk. Epihymenium black, hymenium hyaline 120µm tall, hypothecium light brown, exciple dark brown to nearly black. Asci separating easily from hemenial gels. Exciple thin section areas K+olive green, K/I+blue, wider at base, 25µ at upper hymenium, about 50µ at base of hypothecium. Hymenium K/+ pale blue. Hypothecium persistent K/I+dark blue.
Asci narrowly ellipsoid, 74-97µm, longer lengths include tail at base, 10-12µm wide, K/I+ red with a blue tholus. Spores spiraled in asci, not broken, breaking occasionally in large parts outside ascus. Long, narrow, many-septate (24, 25, 16), with one end narrower, other end blunt, straight or S-shaped. ~60-85×2.4-4.3µm, Longest (middle) cells 3.5-4.3µm,
results.location_name: Los Padres National Forest, Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes:
On redwood (Sequoia sempervirens) dead wood.
Thallus immersed, white. Lichenized with Trentopohlia. Apothecia immersed, round to irregularly elongated, flat, epruinose. Epihymenium and hypothecium ochre, hymenium hyaline and inspersed? With some sterile spores. Asci globose. POL+ white crystals at base and on top of epihymenium, maybe not from secondary substances though. All parts immediately IKI (Lugol’s)+Red persistently. Spores muriform, hyaline, large. 6 transverse septa and 2 lengthwise septa, about 19 cells. 30.0×13.6µm.

results.notes:
Hypomyces rosellus – 50703
Récolté par Jules Cimon
Écologie : forêt mixte
Substrat : polypore résupiné
Période : automne
Comestibilité : non comestible
Réaction chimique : pourpre foncé sur la surface périthéciale

Périthèces jusqu’à 331 µm de hauteur x 250 µm de diam.(0,33 × 0,25 mm), dispersés à grégaires, semi-immergés dans un subiculum souple, rose pourpré, avec ostioles papillés, coniques
Asques *à 8 spores unisériées, avec pore apical inamyloïde, cylindriques, crochetés ou non à la base, jusqu’à 176 × 6,7 µm
Paraphyses absentes
Paroi périthéciale *de texture pseudoparenchymateuse(?) à cellules sub globuleuses à globuleuses entremêlées de cellules cylindriques septées-étranglées ou non, à terminaisons clavées ou cylindriques, rose brunâtre à faiblement pourprées, 22,4 × 19 µm à la base périthéciale, diminuant progressivement de dimension en montant vers les ostioles

Ostioles entourés de cellules cylindriques hyalines en palissades, , jusqu’à 2,7 µm de diam.
Spores fusiformes, verruqueuses latéralement, avec septum médian, biguttulées, effilées à chaque extrémité, hyalines en H2O,
25,6 – 31,9 × 3,8 – 5,4 µm
Me = 28,7 × 4,6 µm
N = 30

NB. Quelques conidies libres isolées, observées en l’absence de conidiophores, ellipsoïdes, arrondies à l’apex, avec 2-3 septa, grand appendice basal trapu, à paroi lisse, hyalines

results.notes:
Growing on fertillized grass, old cow farm. Caespitosa, growing all 5 speciments toghether.
Pileus dry, not observed to be hygrophanous or having a separable pellice, slightly striate, no exceding margin. Presence of diminute white fibrills near and at the pileus margin.
Gills adnate (some speciments decurrent), dark brown, motted with white edge. Spore print black with purple tones.
Stipe whitish without annulus, purinose at the apex, fibrillose at the base.
No bruising blue reaction observed.
At the same location I observe many coprophyle species growing on grass, we cannot discard even the coprophyle Deconica.

Récolté par Jules Cimon
Date de récolte: 2009.07.09
Habitat: lisière de forêt dans une érablière
Hôte: sur bolet sp.

Partie macroscopique formée d’une croûte jaune orangé à brun roux, constituée de périthèces globuleux surmontés d’un ostiole.

Constituants microscopiques:
Asques à 8 spores, unisériées, 92-110 × 4-5 µm en moyenne (5 asques)
Spores naviculaires, verruqueuses, à paroi épaisse, à 1 septum submédian, souvent avec apicule jusqu’à 1 µm de longueur, guttulées, hyalines en NaCl iso.,
12-15 × 3,5-4 µm, 13,5 × 3,8 µm en moyenne (10 spores), Q = 3,55

Étude microscopique et recherche: Jacqueline Labrecque et Roland Labbé

Collaboration: John Plischke
Identification: Jacqueline Labrecque et Roland Labbé

  • Félicitations à Jules Cimon pour cette belle découverte

results.notes: Found growing on top of covered compost pile surrounded one one side by cardboard and slightly covered with oak leaves/mulch. Compost pile protected during winter with cardboard over plastic. Several mushrooms growing close together one atop another and a few tiny ones in “ball” stage underneath the larger ones. Four smaller ones weighed 7 oz each and the largest one was 14 oz. The stem broke apart on largest one as I was twisting it off the dirt – very woody/fibrous stem. I thought they looked like portabellas but not sure. Mild smelling, skin on caps peel off easily. Would have liked to taste if had a positive ID. Please help identify and advise if edible.

results.notes:
Jobellisia luteola
Récolté par Jules cimon le 12 Octobre 2017 sur bois pourri.

Périthèce isolé mais grégaire, non submergé dans le substrat, brunâtre avec méchule(?) orangées. bec présent, distinctivement plus foncé que le reste du champignon.

Asques inamyloides, avec appareil apical au sommet, octosporé, uniserié, jusqu’à 130µ de long, base filiforme. Spores pigmenté, brun foncé avec un faible teint verdâtre. Spores, typiquement asymétrique voir faiblement allantoïdes, avec 1 septum non constricté, les spores mesurent 12µ-14(14 5µ)(4.2)4.5µ-5.7µ, en moyenne 13.2µ5.1µ (environ 25 spores). K = 2.6

Paraphyse simples, filiformes, non clavé et hyalines, diffiçiles à observé. excipulum, texture Prismatica probable.

Texte: Jonathan Mack

results.notes:
Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017). Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Recomendaciones, para que los registros y las descripciones que hagas, te permitan determinar el ejemplar:

-Tomar fotografías de las diferentes estructuras del basidioma/ascoma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), su estipe, pileo y base, en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada. Además de retirarlo con sustrato para conocer otras características de la base del basidioma.

-Es importante que describas las dimensiones (altura y diametro), forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona y temporada en la que crecen, para hacer un seguimiento y logres observar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero).

-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, insectos asociados, etc).

-No olvides que la determinación de macromicetos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de género y especie; en la mayoría) implica actividades de descripción morfológica externa e interna, reacciones químicas, microscopia y ADN.

results.notes:
Macroscopic Features: Dusky orange gilled mushrooms, each perhaps half an inch or less. Flesh tough. Gills crimson, seeming to run directly from the point of attachment to the substrate to the margin, with most gills forking. No stem apparent. Smell/Taste not distinctive.

Occurrence: Growing directly from a rotting stump, with about a dozen growing in close proximity. There were several very old polypores nearby that I did not ID, but these had light orange to tan fertile surface with no gills or ridges apparent, so unlikely to be same species.

Rochester Hills, Oakland Co., Michigan, USA

results.notes:
Macroscopic Features: Dark brown, purplish body growing directly from substrate. Distinct dark orange color at the margin. Surface waxy with a warty, irregular shape. Flesh tough, leathery with orange/brown color (not pictured). Velvety texture at edges and on fertile surface. Fertile surface deep purple/brown or burgundy. Small, circular pores just visible to the naked eye. Smell waxy, woody, sweet with hints of vanilla. Very pleasant! Taste not distinctive.

Occurrence: Growing in a large group on a rotting oak tree

Mushrooms of the Gulf Coast States pointed me towards G Zonatum, G. Curtisii or G. Sessile, but these don’t seem to have the rough/warty surface, the velvety orange margin & fertile surface, or the distinctive smell.

results.notes:
Lachnellula occidentalis
Récolté par Jules Cimon
Date de récolte : 22 / 06 / 2013
Substrat *: branche morte de mélèze
Asques *non operculés, à 8 spores unisériées, avec crochets à la base et pore apical amyloïde avec prétraitement dans le KOH puis dans le Lugol, 110-127 × 9-12 µm
Paraphyses *étroitement cylindriques, parfois légèrement plus larges vers l’apex et avec un septum vers la base, non ramifiées, à contenu lipidique et fines guttules jaunes réfringentes jusqu’à 80% et plus, 113-170 × 2,5-4 µm, dépassant les asques d’environ 5-15 µm
Spores *moyennement à étroitement ellipsoïdes, rarement subfusoïdes, lisses, à paroi légèrement épaissie, avec 1-2 guttules, 12-20,5 × 5,5-7,5 µm, 15,7 × 6,4 µm en moyenne, Q = 2,45
Sous-hyménium formé de petites hyphes emmêlées, sinueuses, septées, 1,5-2 µm de diam.
**Excipulum**en textura prismatica ascendant, gélatinisé, formé d’hyphes septées,à paroi épaissie, 2-3 µm de diam.
Revêtement externe formé de cellules globuleuses à ellipsoïdes, à paroi épaissie, jusqu’à 1 µm de largeur, 7-10 × 6-9 µm
**Medulla**± en textura intricata, à pigment jaunâtre ± gélatinisé, difficile à préciser
Poils marginaux cylindriques, arrondis à l’apex, septés, finement incrustés, hyalins, jusqu’à 150 × 2,2-4 µm

  • Recherche**: R. Labbé
    Identification: Jules Cimon
    Confirmation: *Hans O. Baral
    Texte: J. Labrecque**

results.notes:
The physical observation and the field photographs were done by Fernando Macias.
In small groups, on soil, with scattered grass and in proximity of some hardwoods, in an urban setting.
DESCRIPTION: Cap 2 to 4 cms, red/brown overall, burnt sienna towards the center, more mix with yellow/brown towards the margins, glabrous, margin incurved. We are assuming it to be really viscid; appearing dry and cracking at the time, but with strongly bonded dirt on the cap, and becoming really slippery when adding water.
Gills close, narrow, adnate or sinuate, yellow brown.
Stipe 3-4 cms long, 1 cm wide, white, a little scaly hollow. No annulus observed.
Smell indistinct, taste mild.
Spore print fuscous/brown, a little dark without purple or red tones. Spores (6.8-7.5) x (4.2-4.5) Q =1.64, smooth, elliptic to oblong, with a minuscule germ pore not truncate, with some oil droplets that appear to be dextrinoid (only the droplets reacting).
Basidia (16-20) x 5. Pleurocystida abundant, projecting, ventricose (36-46) x (13-14) x (5-6) with an obtuse apex, smooth, mostly thin walled (the thickest appears to be .8 μ), and in some cases with an amber/brown opaque visible content. Cheilocystidia similar, but smaller.
The pileipelis a tangled cutis, hyphae with smooth walls, clamped at the septa.
COMMENT: The spore print, the pileus cutis, and the abundant projecting pleurocystidia, points to me to Pholiota subgenus Flammuloides. The thin walls on the pleurocystidia and the smaller spores, indicates on the key that could be section Lubricae. With the cap colors been bright orange/red/brown category could be stirps Fibrillosipes. Growing on soil, narrow gills and other microscopic characteristics, could be Pholiota subcarbonaria.
If we choose section Flammuloides as with pleurocystidia thicker than .5μ, and then stirps Ferruginea because the colors they are some other choices that are close, not quite as much. Has anybody have seen this one before? What else could it be?

results.notes:
Same exact fruit bodies as seen in obs 404138 and obs 404577, except one year later.

A wedge cut out last year shows a white fertile surface has grown over the exposed context. Last photo which was taken 3-26-2021.

I scraped a bit of the white hymenium onto a slide and mounted in Congo red. Truncate double walled spores fit the description for G. applanatum (and presumably for G. megaloma).

If G. applanatum does not occur in North America then it appears G. megaloma is the name that applies here. But, I have not found convincing evidence to support either hypothesis. It’s also possible that taxa by either name occur in NA. Some sources report morphological differences.

On underside of well decayed hardwood log.

Spore print visible on a slide. Mounted in Congo red, and then in phenol red (last photo). Found what appear to be broadly ellipsoid to subglobose spores (which fits the expectation for P. crocatus). Also, found cylindric to allantoid (spores?) similar to what I had found with obs 450653. Also large fusoid septate structures that I think may be insect larvae.

These fruit bodies have been attached to the wood for at least several months, possible much longer. I suppose some of what I found with the scope may represent organisms other than the polypore. There were quite a few of the cylindric/allantoid objects. All things seen in micros were collected on a slide via printing. First few micros show a mixture of these objects; last photo shows mostly what appear to be subglobose spores.

KOH black on pore surface (after 3-4 seconds).

Same area/habitat as both obs 404577 and obs 450653.

notes_fields.Habitat: I came across this fungus in Bill’s Woods, which is a disturbed mixed deciduous woodland consisting of woody trees including an assortment of red, white, and burr oak, shagbark hickory, maple, cherry, hackberry, as well as woody shrubs like elderberry. This stretch of the preserve has a storied past, passing through many hands and living many lives before settling as a protected token of the University of Wisconsin-Madison’s land and culture conservation ethic. First, the woods functioned as the ancestral home of the Ho Chunk people and more recently as both a private, working farm and university agricultural research station. With the restoration in progress, spring ephemerals have been finding a firm footing in a once familiar place and are sprouting profusely along the south-facing slopes of the woods this spring. The duff on the forest floor was filled with fallen woody material sitting close to the soil surface.
notes_fields.Substrate: I spotted this resupinate sporocarp on a splintered, shaded flank of a decaying tree trunk just off a footpath. The wood looked to be quite dry and friable. No other fungi were in close proximity to the observed specimen.
notes_fields.Location: This observation site was located off a footpath of Bill’s Woods in the Lakeshore Nature Preserve.

results.notes: Superficially, the fungus had a sclerotized, melanized stroma (about 2 cm in size) that housed perithecia on its textured, dome-shaped surface. A longitudinal cross section revealed a flat mass of sterile mycelia with little to no distinctive patterning. The stroma bodies formed globular clusters in a linear fashion with clear delineations between discrete stromal outgrowths. It is possible age distorted the presence of concentric rings.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Habitat: I found this lichen sitting atop a dead tree limb in Bill’s Woods of the Lakeshore Nature Preserve. Bill’s Woods is a disturbed mixed deciduous forest composed of trees including oak (of these types: red, white, and burr), shagbark hickory, hackberry, maple, cherry, and shrubs like elderberry. Much of this area was extensively farmed in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, which eventually inspired conservationists to reclaim the land and restore it to its former glory. As a result of this disturbance, large swaths of the acreage are exposed, creating an unusually sunny forest floor. Lots of new growth is mixed in with established stands of trees.
notes_fields.Substrate: I spotted this foliose lichen on a decaying tree limb suspended in the air, isolated from any other foliage or decaying material. It stuck out like a sore thumb, contrasting sharply with the nearby bryophytes and detritus wood. The wood was relatively moist due to the moisture-retaining moss on its surface. I could not identify the tree species, but seeing as the felled trunk was quite large, I’m assuming it was one of the genera mentioned in the “Habitat” subheading.
notes_fields.Location: Located on a dead branch in Bill’s Woods, Lakeshore Nature Preserve.

results.notes: The thallus of the lichen was largely lobed and fluoresced a grayish-blue hue. The central regions of the upper cortex were slightly green in color due to the presence of asexual isidia propagules. White punctations littered the surface giving the thallus a textured appearance. Once exposed, the lower cortex revealed a white/cream colored surface.

results.notes:
This “fluffy” fungi was found in a pile of fallen wood brush in Caretaker’s Woods, Madison, WI. The clumps varied in size but all appeared to be a white thready/fluffy consistency. results.notes:
I found this unusual specimen growing from the side of a boxelder log. The second shot is of a crude field sketch, not entirely to scale nor exact in orientation (nor in any other way). Proportions of the dried specimen shots differ from my sketch due to inaccuracies and to differential shrinking on drying.
The ‘face’ shown (in situ) is about 3/4 inch (19 mm) across. The ‘cork’-shaped sporocarp (?) tapered down to a base about half as wide (~3/8 inch = 10 mm) through about 1/4 inch = 6 mm. This ‘base’ was clearly not in contact with the log though the gap was small (exaggerated in the sketch). From the center of this base there issued a fibrous-tough stalk ~ 1/16-1/8 inch in diameter and running at least 3/4 inch into the log, about perpendicularly, to the depth I extracted it. I do not know how much of it I failed to extract.
The tapered ‘sides’ of the sporocarp were not distinctly marked but showed pores at 10X magnification. The photo shows some sort of a mold and discoloration suggesting this is a mature specimen. Other than this coloration was about the same everywhere. I noted a mild, sweet odor. This is the only time I’ve seen such a fungus in this much explored place (or anywhere else).

notes_fields.Habitat: I captured this observation on a south-facing slope in Bill’s Woods (disturbed hardwood forest) of the Lakeshore Nature Preserve. This particular location opened up into a clearing with very little mature growth. There were clear signs of ecological disturbance with cut logs and other clearings nearby.
notes_fields.Substrate: The branch was resting on a decaying tree trunk, both of which were most likely hardwoods. This fungus was gregariously clustered with other members of the same species on a detached, decaying branch. The branch was suspended above the leaf litter and retained little moisture, leaving the substrate quite dry. The fallen branch possibly fell from high in the canopy, so this species may be partial to sunlight.
notes_fields.Location: Found along a sloped incline in Bill’s Woods.

results.notes: The fungi on the branch ranged in size from 0.5 cm to 2.5 cm. They were attached in an effused-reflexed manner with their cream-colored, poroid hymenophores facing down. A few of the caps looked to be connected by lateral fusion. The caps displayed a brilliant white, zonate pattern with alternating light/dark concentric rings and stood in contrast to the dull woodland surroundings.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

These pictures were taken on a warm, 65 degree day (Fahrenheit) in Madison, WI.
Most of the shelves were about 13-15 cm wide. Grayish in color with light brown/black rings. In the cross section you can see the tubules that lead to the spore-dropping underside.

results.notes:
This tiny yellow lichen was found growing on the side of a living tree in Bill’s Woods, Madison, WI. The tree was not coniferous.
These photos were taken on a warm, 65 degree day (fahrenheit).
Looking at the zoomed out image, one can see that there are many types of lichen on this trunk.
This particular segment was less than 1 cm in diameter.
The specimen can be described as a foliose, yellow-green lichen with visible lobes.
The surrounding forest floor was very dry and leaf-filled.
I chose Candelaria as the genus for this collection because – compared to Xanthomendoza – it is less orange and more lemon colored.
However, I wouldn’t rule out the possibility of it being Xanthomendoza entirely.

results.notes:
Spores: Simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. 5 measured: 6.8×3.7, 7.9×3.7, 8.1×4.0, 8.1×3.6, 7.4×3.2 um. MANY spores per ascus (could easily be 100+).

Macro: Brownish-yellow squamules, almost lobate, squamules convex with margins on large squamules inrolled. Haven’t looked at attachment structures yet; could be peltate or stipitate squamules. Apothecia immersed, small (largest ~0.1 mm), black. Largest squam 1.5 mm wide.

Micro: photobiont a unicellular cyanobacterium. Cortex a gold-yellow color, paraplectenchymatous, not well differentiated from medulla (though clear cells could be dead photobiont cells I guess, making it an epinecral layer). No coherent lower cortex as far as I can tell. Non-algal cells in algal layer: some cellular, rounded (or poss. dead algal cells), others elongated hyphae. Apothecium: orange epihymenium with thin, possibly necral layer overlaying it. Hymenium hyaline, ~90 um, inspersed with many small oil droplets I think. Area below hymenium not well differentiated. Proper exciple not obvious/indistinct.

Chemistry: epihymenium and rest of ap/thallus K- in section. Entire apothecium strongly I+ blue after K application.

4/13/21 additional data: lower cortex confirmed. Composed of round cells, measured in three places: 25, 26, and 36 micrometers. Algal layer: composed of elongated hyphae, loosely interwoven, prone to getting filled with air in slide. One hyphal width measureement: 3.5 micrometers. On the larger squamules, there appear to be 5+ apothecia, though some just barely appear as punctiform black dots on thallus surface.

notes_fields.Habitat: I was ambling up an east-facing slope in Bill’s Woods (a disturbed, temperate hardwood forest) when I came across this fleshy creature set atop a rotting tree trunk. This particular slope is covered with fallen timber and other forestry detritus products, most likely the result of restoration projects. So, there is ample material for saprobic fungi to colonize and feast on senescent plant products. Just beyond the slope lies a deserted apple orchard that has seen better days. It’s possible the close proximity to the obsolete apple orchard has something to do with the diversity of fungi in this woodland area. This fungus was growing gregariously with a few other members of what looked to be the same species.
notes_fields.Substrate: Many bryophytes were clustered around the fungus, retaining water, and, in doing so, created a moist microclimate for the fungus. The wood was at an advanced stage in the decomposition process with nondescript features, almost too decayed to identify to species. Bill’s Woods hosts many hardwood species so I’m assuming the tree trunk in question was of the hardwood type. However, members of this genus are also known to favor coniferous substrates, especially if proven to be Gyromitra and not Peziza.
notes_fields.Location: This fungus was spotted in Bill’s Woods at the perimeter of the old apple orchard, a well-known patch of land once dedicated to pome production.

results.notes: The fungus was roughly 3 cm in size and was attached by a single, rudimentary stem to the woody material below. The apothecial cup was a soft orange, peach color, and the underside was a few shades lighter than the upper cup. The cup margin was not completely contiguous, with an invagination-like point at which the ridge turned in towards the center of the cup creating a wrinkled texture. The order Pezizales also encompasses the false morels (Gyromitra) and true morels (Morchella).
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA
